This idea now that we're allowing people to get out of an entitlement program which is Obamacare, of course it's terrifying to Democrats because that mean that people can spend their own money and buy their own health care, opening up a whole another market which is an indictment of government run health insurance.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: If you look at the bill and the contents of the bill, Democrats have been arguing for decades that they are the champions of the middle- class. Here we are with an actual piece of legislation that is going to give the middle class a tax cut across the board. And guess what, people in the higher tax brackets are going to get a tax hike. So why are Democrats complaining about it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Audience, go look for yourself an independent analysis. Nobody thinks that the rich and corporations are taking a tax hike.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know what I think was Armageddon, the Obamacare website.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: John Conyers is out of congress for now. There's a twist, up next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Today, John Conyers became the first member of congress to give up his seat amid a national reckoning on sexual harassment. He was facing intense pressure to resign after multiple misconducts claims surfaced over the last two weeks. He announced his retirement on a radio show this morning, but still denies the allegations against him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Is this royalty or a republic? I mean, we don't know anything about his son. The apple may not far from the underwear. So I don't know. I don't think it's right for him to keep it in the family. I don't think you should be allowed to do that. But by the way, comparing this to all the other revelations hitting media, politics, entertainment, he's getting off pretty easy. I mean, he's 88 and he's retiring, it's not like he's losing his career at the age of 40 or 35 or 50, I mean, this is not a tragedy. He's 88-years-old. Go spend some time, you know, other things that don't involve changing your clothes in front of people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's pretty much tragic when a guy who was the longest serving member and who was revered by many in the black community, certainly in Michigan, ends up in this kind -- I mean, his whole legacy I think is tarnished. And I think that's why today he said in terms of his son. I don't know his son either. But he said my legacy will continue through my -- because the guy understand that he will be remembered in these terms and not as the guy, for example, introduced a legislation to honor Dr. King -- with the national holiday for the birthday. That's damaging.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It's a good lesson for lawmakers on Capitol Hill, for men in big powerful positions. They do a lot of good things throughout their life, that is true, but when it comes to this kind of behavior, you might get away with it for 10 years or 20 years, but eventually it will catch up to you. That is exactly what happened now. My question is, going into 2018 midterm elections, how are Democrats going to play this politically? Are they now going to be the party that takes the high road on sexual harassment and assault claims and try to have some kind of standard for lawmakers when they are accused or when there are credible accusations that they stepped down. Is Al Franken going to be someone who is -- who is also pressured into maybe stepping aside in a safe -- safe-ish Democrat seat? 2018 is going to be interesting to see how this narrative about this issue plays out in politics, because as we've seen with Republicans with the Alabama Senate race, they've chosen a different way of handling the issue. Right? So going into...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me hear that. I want to hear that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: They've just chosen, based on how Democrats have reacted for 30 years of sexual assault claims like Bill Clinton, just double down, deny, drag the victims through the mud. They've taken that playbook and used it and said, "We're not going to give up our power, because Democrats never do. And if we're all going to be in the dirt on this thing, well, then we're going to have our own people who are going to a vote for an agenda doing -- doing that voting." Whereas maybe...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Do you think it's comparable? Do you think it's comparable what Roy Moore is accused of doing?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I'm not comparing them. I'm just saying generally.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because I don't see any -- I don't think it's comparable, what Al Franken or John Conyers touching a woman with, in terms of Roy Moore asking 14-year-olds to take their clothes off.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That is an allegation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what I said.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But there is an investigation going forward on it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What about -- in these other instances, there's photographic evidence. There's money paid. So that point is you have to have due process with each situation. We're not trying to say, "OK, this is pretty bad. This is really bad. This is so, so." It's just, "OK, has there been a settlement paid? OK. Is there photographic evidence or otherwise or eyewitnesses percipient to the time when the assault or the conduct occurred?" That's how you run an investigation. That's what we do in this country. We don't just say something because someone's been accused of it and say, "All right. Fine, you're done. That's not how it works."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But that -- Conyers didn't have any investigation. He just -- he's been forced to resign...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: He paid -- he paid up. He paid them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: ... by Democrats...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: ... because of his behavior and because...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Midterm elections coming up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no. I was going to go to her point, which is that apparently, he used office money, taxpayer dollars as hush money.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's bad, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But that has -- that is not to say that this is comparable to what Roy Moore did.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I was not comparing them. I was simply saying there's -- the issue of sexual harassment and sexual assault, to whatever degree, is going to be a political topic...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: ... in the 2018 midterms. And it will be interesting to see how Democrats handle it, and it will be interesting to see how Republicans handle it, as well.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK. So Jesse, rain brilliance.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, well, listen, he did the right thing. It took him a little while to get there. He was a lame duck. And a sitting duck, because he could have been blackmailed, too. And remember how the Democrats got here. First they said he was iconic. Then they raised doubts about the accusers. Then they played the race card. So the guy was old. It was a safe seat. It's Congress; it's not a Senate seat. It's a lot easier to kick a guy out like that. But there's a lot of lessons here. The public will not stomach a sexual harassment settlement with taxpayer money. They just won't. Also, another takeaway: whenever you settle, especially more than one suit, you're always going to be assumed to be guilty in the court of public opinion. And every case is different. And in politics you have a long leash to fight these allegations. In the private sector, one accusation, good night. And I think, you know, the bottom line, there's a lot of talented and very successful guys. We've known them. We've -- we've been around them. And they're deeply flawed. And it's very complicated, and it's very sad to see. And you feel sorry for the victims. You feel sorry for the people involved, but you know, it happens and, you know, it's not a good thing. And we shouldn't be celebrating it either.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There needs to be a retirement home.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All of -- there are so many of these guys. Like, where are they going? They just go off and they disappear. There needs to be a place for them, where they could just -- just for them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just for them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A closed-robe curfew at 10 p.m.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: All righty. More drama from self-promoter Lavar Ball ahead on "The Five." First, here's LiAngelo Ball in a new interview, talking about what he did overseas.

utterances.speaker: LIANGELO BALL, ARRESTED IN CHINA
utterances.sentences: We all went out one night, went to the malls, went to the Louis Vuitton store. And people started taking stuff and then, you know, me just not thinking and being with them, I took something, too. I didn't realize until I got back to the hotel, I'm like, "That was stupid." Sure enough, the next morning the police came and got us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: LiAngelo was among three players suspended from the UCLA basketball team. Now Papa isn't happy his son is benched, so he's yanked him out of the university. Here's why.

utterances.speaker: LAVAR BALL, FATHER OF LIANGELO
utterances.sentences: China already said, "OK, he made a bad mistake. We're going to drop the charges." That's the punishment they gave him. Now we over here, look at we've got to serve some more punishment? He apologized. What is the long process for? We only went to UCLA, one and done, to play basketball. I'm going to get JELL-O and shake (ph). We're going to do some other things, and he's going to be headed to the NBA.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. Now let me tell you something. I just think this dad who seems to me is like just, you know, I mean, he is like a black Trump. He's just talking, talking, talking.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Saying stuff, selling whoop tickets. But why he would say this about his son, I don't get it. Because I think the son was lucky to get out of jail in China.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So do you want to start?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Where do you begin? Where do you begin? But it sounds like he's had some discussions with teams or where he thinks his son's just going to go right to the NBA?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But no, in fact, the NBA general managers, Kimberly, have said this kid is not an all-star. Remember, his brother, who plays for the Lakers.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but don't tell it to Lavar Ball. Because if he says it, it's so ordained. I mean, I don't know. I felt bad for the kid. He's kind of sitting there, like, "Whatever." What can you say? I think his dad is, like, running the show. And he's, like, the equivalent of, like, a stage mom. I don't know. Like his son is in the pageants. And he's like "This is what you're going to do."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Does this work out, Jesse? What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, it doesn't. But this guy has more charisma in his pinky than I think most all of us. I love to watch him on television. He's fantastic, but now the rest of the country is getting to see what a wacko this guy really is. He's basically pulling his son out of UCLA so he doesn't have to suffer the consequences for stealing. So he's going to go one and done at another school? No, he's not. NBA scout says he's not a first round, second round or he's not even on the radar. Furthermore, the bloom is off the rose with the Ball boys. The guy on the Lakers is having a terrible year. He's really underperforming. This guy, they don't want to sign a family like this.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This guy gets in front of the camera, he steals the limelight.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I guess.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No owner is going to want to deal with this family. It's nothing but trouble.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The P.R. department is like "No, thank you."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Do not have him come here.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Like Colin Kaepernick.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: By the way, on that point, the Lakers had to change their policy about reporters talking to family and loved ones behind...

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Families cause problems sometimes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. They call it the Lavar Ball Rule.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: On a more serious note, all right, I think that this father needs to YouTube some videos, do some research, read about what it means to be in a Chinese prison for ten years. And this is the reason why consequences are important. The consequences matter. For him to say that he was treated worse at UCLA than he would be treated in China, he was looking at ten years in prison and a communist country where they don't really care about your well-being. They don't care about human rights. And the idea that they are now being so arrogant and ignorant about what the consequences were going to be actually is pretty insulting the people who, I don't know, like Nobel Peace Prize winners wives who have been in Chinese prisons for simply being a dissident in the government. I mean, there's a lot that goes on in China, and this kid is really, really, really lucky that he didn't get stuck there for ten years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, Katie makes such an important point, but I want to talk about silliness, Greg. And the silliness is that Lavar also sent a pair of sneakers, red, white, and blue, to President Trump. But he says the president hasn't thanked him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They are kindred -- they are kindred spirits.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm going to defend the father. If you're -- if you're majoring in molecular biology and you're suspended indefinitely from the lab, what do you do? You've got to leave school. He's -- the father is honest. His son is only there to play basketball, and if he's not playing basketball, what's the point? Study? Please.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: An indefinite suspension is, in effect, asking him to leave.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. But what about -- and I think lots of people on this...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: What about a great education?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: At UCLA? Come on.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You've got to go to UC Davis.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Berkeley. Berkeley is way better. UCLA is like the basement school of UC, the UC system. You go to UCLA just for the weather. You go to Berkeley for the brains.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me just say, as a dad, it's important not to tell your kids it's OK to steal. That -- like that was wrong. You've got to send some lessons. How young is too young to be on social media? Controversy over Facebook's new app for kids coming up next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: The basement.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: As if kids aren't already glued to their smartphones, Facebook is giving the more reasons to be addicted to their devices. The social media giant is now targeting preteens with a new app called Messenger Kids. It requires parents of children under 13 to approve contact so they can chat with their friends and doodle on pictures they send to one another. Facebook says the point of it is to provide a more controlled environment for kids who are already connecting with each other on their phones. But of course, there's always concern about safety when it comes to children. So I'm going to defer to the parents on this side of the table.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: As a kid who wasn't even allowed to watch MTV, this freaks me out a little bit. But it seems like they've put some things in place to make sure the kids are safe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm afraid my daughters are going to go on Facebook and write nasty things under my videos on my page.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Oh, anonymously.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's my biggest fear. I don't want them on screens any more than they already are. They're already watching too much TV. I can't control it. They're on my phone. They're on everyone's phone. I don't like it. I want them to play outside and use their imagination. I think that's healthy. And it's a magnet for perverts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Hey!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Can you get on there and pretend you're 13 and then you're really 45 and go on and start conversating?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: According to Facebook, they have implemented a number of restrictions so that parents have to approve who the kids are talking to. The contacts have to be approved. The kids don't actually sign up for the account. It's through the parents. So essentially, it's just something on the parents phone or iPad that they can...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's probably a bunch of Russian bots or something like that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Maybe that's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Blame it on the Russians.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Always the collusion with the Russians.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I think this is well-intentioned. Right? I mean, I don't know. We'll have to see how it works out. There's not a lot of buzz in it, in terms of, yes, like Jesse says, people being able to breach or get on there to use it for untoward, inappropriate purposes. So we have to watch out for that. But in general, parents have to monitor and have, you know, I guess, like, guides on there and to make sure, and restrictions on a lot of things.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Juan...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Your cable, too.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: ... are screens melting the brains of the youth? That's why everyone hates millennial s?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think there's any question it changes the way your brain works in the way you interact socially with people. The big question is the one Jesse touched on, which is, you know, people who would approach these young people over social media in ways that you can't trace as a parent, as a responsible adult. Liberals only feel outrage if they can direct it at Marxist progressive approved enemy which is the west. So when it's climate change or the election or taxes, you are evil because you're the west. You can ever say anything about ISIS or terror in the same vein.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So Republicans are more deadly than ISIS.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that what you're getting? It's like the boy who cried wolf. How long can they keep this up?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: This is such a lazy argument that they made. I mean, remember the Nancy Pelosi allies ran with Paul Ryan pushing an old grandma off a cliff when they're trying to do Medicaid -- Medicare reform, excuse me. I mean, this is an argument they've been using forever. And now I understand after hearing from Larry Summers why the Obama economy was so bad. And for him to suggest that because people are forced to buy Obamacare, that they somehow have health care is a complete and outer lie. The insurance under Obamacare doesn't necessarily provide you any health care, first of all, because it's too expensive. And second of all, because there's -- not enough doctors now and the demand for health care has gone through the roof as a result. Waiting time for health care had increased. Rural hospitals have closed. This idea now that we're allowing people to get out of an entitlement program which is Obamacare, of course it's terrifying to Democrats because that mean that people can spend their own money and buy their own health care, opening up a whole another market which is an indictment of government run health insurance.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you know what really kill people, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Tell me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Obama V.A. scandal. People actually died there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah. But let me just tell you, Katie. I think that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . there's more people covered by insurance because.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Because they are forced to buy it, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying, more people have health insurance which is good for us all.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Because the government tells them they're going to be fine if they can't buy it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's horrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No effect on health.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It does. But let me just say something -- oh, if you don't have health insurance, try to be healthy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're studies that show.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Juan, people don't have health insurance under Obamacare because it's too expensive.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Let me get back to what Greg was talking about though, because it seems to me you ignore something that Republicans had endorsed for years, which is the joint commission on taxation, the official scorekeeper of congress, saying that everyone who makes less than $75,000 is going to see a tax increase under this in ten years. You don't notice that -- oh, my gosh, Republicans have always been deficit hawks, and what do we see from the official scorekeeper, 1.5 trillion additional costs added to our deficit. So it seems to me like you don't have to say Armageddon. I think she's trying to be hyperbolic, you know, because she's trying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So you agree with me?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think she is right when she says -- and by the way, most Americans -- guess what, most Americans agree this is a bad bill.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not crazy about the bill, but I'm not setting my hair on fire.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So why are you over there defending it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm condemning the behavior, the behavior which is hypocritical. They don't act this way when it comes to existential threats.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: On the fact that Democrats criticize it even though you don't like the bill yourself.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But Juan agrees with what you said.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He says, you know, very liberal use of hyperbole. And then he said the language was hyperbole.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You live in a hyperbolic chamber.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Only you were confused, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: If you look at the bill and the contents of the bill, Democrats have been arguing for decades that they are the champions of the middle- class. Here we are with an actual piece of legislation that is going to give the middle class a tax cut across the board. And guess what, people in the higher tax brackets are going to get a tax hike. So why are Democrats complaining about it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Audience, go look for yourself an independent analysis. Nobody thinks that the rich and corporations are taking a tax hike.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what I think was Armageddon, the Obamacare website.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: John Conyers is out of congress for now. There's a twist, up next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Today, John Conyers became the first member of congress to give up his seat amid a national reckoning on sexual harassment. He was facing intense pressure to resign after multiple misconducts claims surfaced over the last two weeks. He announced his retirement on a radio show this morning, but still denies the allegations against him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is this royalty or a republic? I mean, we don't know anything about his son. The apple may not far from the underwear. So I don't know. I don't think it's right for him to keep it in the family. I don't think you should be allowed to do that. But by the way, comparing this to all the other revelations hitting media, politics, entertainment, he's getting off pretty easy. I mean, he's 88 and he's retiring, it's not like he's losing his career at the age of 40 or 35 or 50, I mean, this is not a tragedy. He's 88-years-old. Go spend some time, you know, other things that don't involve changing your clothes in front of people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's pretty much tragic when a guy who was the longest serving member and who was revered by many in the black community, certainly in Michigan, ends up in this kind -- I mean, his whole legacy I think is tarnished. And I think that's why today he said in terms of his son. I don't know his son either. But he said my legacy will continue through my -- because the guy understand that he will be remembered in these terms and not as the guy, for example, introduced a legislation to honor Dr. King -- with the national holiday for the birthday. That's damaging.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's a good lesson for lawmakers on Capitol Hill, for men in big powerful positions. They do a lot of good things throughout their life, that is true, but when it comes to this kind of behavior, you might get away with it for 10 years or 20 years, but eventually it will catch up to you. That is exactly what happened now. My question is, going into 2018 midterm elections, how are Democrats going to play this politically? Are they now going to be the party that takes the high road on sexual harassment and assault claims and try to have some kind of standard for lawmakers when they are accused or when there are credible accusations that they stepped down. Is Al Franken going to be someone who is -- who is also pressured into maybe stepping aside in a safe -- safe-ish Democrat seat? 2018 is going to be interesting to see how this narrative about this issue plays out in politics, because as we've seen with Republicans with the Alabama Senate race, they've chosen a different way of handling the issue. Right? So going into...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me hear that. I want to hear that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: They've just chosen, based on how Democrats have reacted for 30 years of sexual assault claims like Bill Clinton, just double down, deny, drag the victims through the mud. They've taken that playbook and used it and said, "We're not going to give up our power, because Democrats never do. And if we're all going to be in the dirt on this thing, well, then we're going to have our own people who are going to a vote for an agenda doing -- doing that voting." Whereas maybe...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you think it's comparable? Do you think it's comparable what Roy Moore is accused of doing?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I'm not comparing them. I'm just saying generally.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because I don't see any -- I don't think it's comparable, what Al Franken or John Conyers touching a woman with, in terms of Roy Moore asking 14-year-olds to take their clothes off.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That is an allegation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I said.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But there is an investigation going forward on it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What about -- in these other instances, there's photographic evidence. There's money paid. So that point is you have to have due process with each situation. We're not trying to say, "OK, this is pretty bad. This is really bad. This is so, so." It's just, "OK, has there been a settlement paid? OK. Is there photographic evidence or otherwise or eyewitnesses percipient to the time when the assault or the conduct occurred?" That's how you run an investigation. That's what we do in this country. We don't just say something because someone's been accused of it and say, "All right. Fine, you're done. That's not how it works."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But that -- Conyers didn't have any investigation. He just -- he's been forced to resign...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He paid -- he paid up. He paid them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ... by Democrats...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ... because of his behavior and because...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Midterm elections coming up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. I was going to go to her point, which is that apparently, he used office money, taxpayer dollars as hush money.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's bad, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But that has -- that is not to say that this is comparable to what Roy Moore did.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I was not comparing them. I was simply saying there's -- the issue of sexual harassment and sexual assault, to whatever degree, is going to be a political topic...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: ... in the 2018 midterms. And it will be interesting to see how Democrats handle it, and it will be interesting to see how Republicans handle it, as well.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. So Jesse, rain brilliance.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, well, listen, he did the right thing. It took him a little while to get there. He was a lame duck. And a sitting duck, because he could have been blackmailed, too. And remember how the Democrats got here. First they said he was iconic. Then they raised doubts about the accusers. Then they played the race card. So the guy was old. It was a safe seat. It's Congress; it's not a Senate seat. It's a lot easier to kick a guy out like that.

utterances.speaker: But there's a lot of lessons here. The public will not stomach a sexual harassment settlement with taxpayer money. They just won't. Also, another takeaway
utterances.utterance: whenever you settle, especially more than one suit, you're always going to be assumed to be guilty in the court of public opinion. And every case is different. And in politics you have a long leash to fight these allegations. In the private sector, one accusation, good night. And I think, you know, the bottom line, there's a lot of talented and very successful guys. We've known them. We've -- we've been around them. And they're deeply flawed. And it's very complicated, and it's very sad to see. And you feel sorry for the victims. You feel sorry for the people involved, but you know, it happens and, you know, it's not a good thing. And we shouldn't be celebrating it either.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There needs to be a retirement home.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All of -- there are so many of these guys. Like, where are they going? They just go off and they disappear. There needs to be a place for them, where they could just -- just for them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just for them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A closed-robe curfew at 10 p.m.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All righty. More drama from self-promoter Lavar Ball ahead on "The Five." First, here's LiAngelo Ball in a new interview, talking about what he did overseas.

utterances.speaker: LIANGELO BALL, ARRESTED IN CHINA
utterances.utterance: We all went out one night, went to the malls, went to the Louis Vuitton store. And people started taking stuff and then, you know, me just not thinking and being with them, I took something, too. I didn't realize until I got back to the hotel, I'm like, "That was stupid." Sure enough, the next morning the police came and got us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: LiAngelo was among three players suspended from the UCLA basketball team. Now Papa isn't happy his son is benched, so he's yanked him out of the university. Here's why.

utterances.speaker: LAVAR BALL, FATHER OF LIANGELO
utterances.utterance: China already said, "OK, he made a bad mistake. We're going to drop the charges." That's the punishment they gave him. Now we over here, look at we've got to serve some more punishment? He apologized. What is the long process for? We only went to UCLA, one and done, to play basketball. I'm going to get JELL-O and shake (ph). We're going to do some other things, and he's going to be headed to the NBA.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. Now let me tell you something. I just think this dad who seems to me is like just, you know, I mean, he is like a black Trump. He's just talking, talking, talking.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Saying stuff, selling whoop tickets. But why he would say this about his son, I don't get it. Because I think the son was lucky to get out of jail in China.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So do you want to start?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Where do you begin? Where do you begin? But it sounds like he's had some discussions with teams or where he thinks his son's just going to go right to the NBA?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But no, in fact, the NBA general managers, Kimberly, have said this kid is not an all-star. Remember, his brother, who plays for the Lakers.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, but don't tell it to Lavar Ball. Because if he says it, it's so ordained. I mean, I don't know. I felt bad for the kid. He's kind of sitting there, like, "Whatever." What can you say? I think his dad is, like, running the show. And he's, like, the equivalent of, like, a stage mom. I don't know. Like his son is in the pageants. And he's like "This is what you're going to do."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Does this work out, Jesse? What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, it doesn't. But this guy has more charisma in his pinky than I think most all of us. I love to watch him on television. He's fantastic, but now the rest of the country is getting to see what a wacko this guy really is. He's basically pulling his son out of UCLA so he doesn't have to suffer the consequences for stealing. So he's going to go one and done at another school? No, he's not. NBA scout says he's not a first round, second round or he's not even on the radar. Furthermore, the bloom is off the rose with the Ball boys. The guy on the Lakers is having a terrible year. He's really underperforming. This guy, they don't want to sign a family like this.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This guy gets in front of the camera, he steals the limelight.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I guess.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No owner is going to want to deal with this family. It's nothing but trouble.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The P.R. department is like "No, thank you."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Do not have him come here.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Like Colin Kaepernick.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, on that point, the Lakers had to change their policy about reporters talking to family and loved ones behind...

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. Families cause problems sometimes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. They call it the Lavar Ball Rule.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: On a more serious note, all right, I think that this father needs to YouTube some videos, do some research, read about what it means to be in a Chinese prison for ten years. And this is the reason why consequences are important. The consequences matter. For him to say that he was treated worse at UCLA than he would be treated in China, he was looking at ten years in prison and a communist country where they don't really care about your well-being. They don't care about human rights. And the idea that they are now being so arrogant and ignorant about what the consequences were going to be actually is pretty insulting the people who, I don't know, like Nobel Peace Prize winners wives who have been in Chinese prisons for simply being a dissident in the government. I mean, there's a lot that goes on in China, and this kid is really, really, really lucky that he didn't get stuck there for ten years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, Katie makes such an important point, but I want to talk about silliness, Greg. And the silliness is that Lavar also sent a pair of sneakers, red, white, and blue, to President Trump. But he says the president hasn't thanked him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They are kindred -- they are kindred spirits.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm going to defend the father. If you're -- if you're majoring in molecular biology and you're suspended indefinitely from the lab, what do you do? You've got to leave school. He's -- the father is honest. His son is only there to play basketball, and if he's not playing basketball, what's the point? Study? Please.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: An indefinite suspension is, in effect, asking him to leave.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. But what about -- and I think lots of people on this...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What about a great education?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: At UCLA? Come on.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You've got to go to UC Davis.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Berkeley. Berkeley is way better. UCLA is like the basement school of UC, the UC system. You go to UCLA just for the weather. You go to Berkeley for the brains.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just say, as a dad, it's important not to tell your kids it's OK to steal. That -- like that was wrong. You've got to send some lessons. How young is too young to be on social media? Controversy over Facebook's new app for kids coming up next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The basement.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: As if kids aren't already glued to their smartphones, Facebook is giving the more reasons to be addicted to their devices. The social media giant is now targeting preteens with a new app called Messenger Kids. It requires parents of children under 13 to approve contact so they can chat with their friends and doodle on pictures they send to one another. Facebook says the point of it is to provide a more controlled environment for kids who are already connecting with each other on their phones. But of course, there's always concern about safety when it comes to children. So I'm going to defer to the parents on this side of the table.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: As a kid who wasn't even allowed to watch MTV, this freaks me out a little bit. But it seems like they've put some things in place to make sure the kids are safe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm afraid my daughters are going to go on Facebook and write nasty things under my videos on my page.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, anonymously.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's my biggest fear. I don't want them on screens any more than they already are. They're already watching too much TV. I can't control it. They're on my phone. They're on everyone's phone. I don't like it. I want them to play outside and use their imagination. I think that's healthy. And it's a magnet for perverts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Hey!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Can you get on there and pretend you're 13 and then you're really 45 and go on and start conversating?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: According to Facebook, they have implemented a number of restrictions so that parents have to approve who the kids are talking to. The contacts have to be approved. The kids don't actually sign up for the account. It's through the parents. So essentially, it's just something on the parents phone or iPad that they can...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's probably a bunch of Russian bots or something like that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Maybe that's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Blame it on the Russians.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Always the collusion with the Russians.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think this is well-intentioned. Right? I mean, I don't know. We'll have to see how it works out. There's not a lot of buzz in it, in terms of, yes, like Jesse says, people being able to breach or get on there to use it for untoward, inappropriate purposes. So we have to watch out for that. But in general, parents have to monitor and have, you know, I guess, like, guides on there and to make sure, and restrictions on a lot of things.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Juan...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Your cable, too.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: ... are screens melting the brains of the youth? That's why everyone hates millennial s?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think there's any question it changes the way your brain works in the way you interact socially with people. The big question is the one Jesse touched on, which is, you know, people who would approach these young people over social media in ways that you can't trace as a parent, as a responsible adult. And then set up tragedy. So, I mean, we live in an era of a lot of this kind of, you know, sexual stuff; and we don't need it. I mean, kids should not be exposed to that, even if it's of their own choosing.

utterances.speaker: One final point
utterances.utterance: I think Facebook is in this for the business.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let's not think that they're being so...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trying to get more users.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Sure, and they're trying to set the kids up to stay on it. Because right now, more kids are using Snapchat and Kick and other stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's their business plan.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, they say they've implemented safety filters about nudity, sexual content, violence. And a report team can -- a support team that can respond to any kind of flagged content. But the other thing, Greg, they have on this, which doesn't make sense based on the guidelines, is parents can't spy on their kids' conversations.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's no fun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's actually...

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: This is 13 and under. Right? So you'd think you'd want to be able to read.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's actually -- this is a really bad idea, and I'm going to stray from everyone's concerns. It's not strangers that ruin your life. It's you who ruin your life. You are handing something that makes permanent the things that they say. Now, have you ever listened to a child?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The things they say make no sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I was just called Poop Dad the other day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. And you know what that means?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Listen up. In some parts of this town, it's not pretty, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Eww!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Children have a hard enough time -- a hard enough time communicating in real life. If they go -- they're going onto a network where what they say is permanent.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And we know young people are ruining their careers...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: ... and their lives right now for stupid tweets. These children will no -- we say children of the future. No, because they will -- they will no longer have a future because of this crap they said when they were 12 and they were 13. And what if there's -- they can say stuff about you. They can go on there and say, "Oh, last night Daddy and Mommy were smoking cigarettes that smelled really funny, and then they were eating bowls of Cool Whip." They could start talk -- they could ruin your reputation. And that stuff, it's a permanent bathroom wall. I mean, adults are ruining their lives. They're losing their jobs for old tweets. This is not a good thing for parents. And a stranger isn't going to ruin your kids' life. The kid will be fine doing it themselves.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So then you're talking they have to be off of social media and not have these accounts. Which by the way, a lot of my friends in the FBI say that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Children should be placed in boxes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Be very careful what you do. And don't have your children on Snapchat or Instagram accounts or things like that...

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
